results.abstract: Hubble Space Telescope, which was given death sentence when former NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe stopped shuttle flights to service it, is revived by new administrator Michael D Griffin, who has announced repair flight in spring 2008 to rejuvenate telescope; other changes at agency described; drawing (M)

headline.main: Hubble, NASA's Comeback Kid, Survives to See a New Dawn

results.snippet: If all goes well, the Hubble Space Telescope will continue to send back cosmic postcards long after the space shuttles that launched and nurtured it have been retired.
results.lead_paragraph: The last time the Hubble Space Telescope was in the news, it had been figuratively tied to the railroad tracks and left for dead by Sean O'Keefe, then the NASA administrator. After the wreck of the space shuttle Columbia, Mr. O'Keefe, who even had a mustache suitable for diabolical twirling, declared an end to the astronaut service calls that had kept the Hubble eye alive and on its game, all but ensuring that its string of matchless cosmic postcards would cease by the end of the decade.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery moves to launch pad awaiting liftoff that could be as early as Dec 7; photo (M)
results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery was moved to the launching pad to await a launch that could be as early as Dec. 7, an effort to avoid potential New Year’s Eve computer glitches.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery was moved to the launching pad on Thursday to await a liftoff that could be as early as Dec. 7, an effort to avoid potential New Year's Eve computer glitches. The worry is that shuttle computers are not designed to make the change from the 365th day of the old year to the first day of the new one while in flight. NASA has never had a shuttle in space on Dec. 31 or Jan. 1.

results.abstract: Tim Blake Nelson article on how he approaches comic role in film, especially question of how closely an outrageous character should be grounded in reality (M)
results.snippet: To exaggerate or not to exaggerate? For serious actors taking on comic roles, that is an important question.
results.lead_paragraph: In a hotelroom in Los Angeles the night before my first day as Gideon, the quasi demented futuristic jailer in Steven Spielberg's ''Minority Report,'' my wife, who was helping me learn my lines, looked up from the script and said, ''Why are you trying to make this guy so normal?''

results.abstract: Steve Smith reviews new two-CD set featuring Gustav Holst's The Planets plus Asteroids, newly commissioned works by four prominent contemporary composers, performed by Berlin Philharmonic conducted by Simon Rattle (M)

headline.main: Composers Weigh In on the Cosmos

results.snippet: Simon Rattle's timely release of “The Planets” includes strong new works by four prominent contemporary composers.
results.lead_paragraph: SIMON RATTLE'S new recording of ''The Planets,'' for EMI Classics, has made headlines of an unusual sort. The British composer Gustav Holst completed the work in 1916: an orchestral suite with a movement devoted to each of the seven planets then known, excluding Earth. That left Pluto, discovered only in 1930 (four years before Holst's death), out in the cold. Another British composer, Colin Matthews, supplied the missing movement, ''Pluto, the Renewer,'' in 2000. It has been recorded before, but Mr. Rattle's two-CD set, with the Berlin Philharmonic, draws particular attention to it, packaging it along with newly commissioned works, called ''Asteroids,'' by four prominent contemporary composers. And the release came just in time for the deflating announcement by the International Astronomical Union that Pluto was being demoted to the status of dwarf planet.

results.abstract: Nike opens store in New York City to sell Lebron James basketball sneakers and closes store after sale; photo (M)

headline.main: Nike Pops Up in SoHo, Sells $250 Sneakers, and Leaves

results.snippet: The store sold the only 250 existing pairs of Nike’s new basketball shoe named for LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers.
results.lead_paragraph: Nike, which is paying the basketball star LeBron James $90 million to wear its sneakers, is far too shrewd a company not to see a promotional opportunity in the fact that Mr. James's team, the Cleveland Cavaliers, was in New York on Monday night to play the Knicks. Never mind that the professional basketball season, which lasts nearly eight months if one counts the playoffs, was less than two weeks old. And never mind that the Knicks are once again likely to contend for the worst record in the league. Never mind, either, that the Cavaliers play the Knicks three or four times a year.

results.snippet: When it comes to making a career decision, Turner Broadcasting Chairman and Chief Executive Philip Kent challenges himself with this mantra: "God hates a coward."

byline.original: By PHILIP KENT; As told to Caroline Wilbert

results.lead_paragraph: I DON'T know exactly where I came up with this career decision mantra, but I often like to challenge myself: ''God hates a coward.'' That's enabled me to take chances professionally and to take two sabbaticals to travel around the world. I never worried I wouldn't find another job. I do think my upbringing helped, in that my parents were neither overprotective nor underprotective. I grew up in a middle-class home in White Plains and went to public school. I had friends who lived in big homes and friends who lived in housing projects. I never saw a big difference in terms of how happy they were.

results.abstract: A golf company buys time ad time on the International Space Station... what's next?
results.snippet: A golf company buys time ad time on the International Space Station... what's next?
results.lead_paragraph: Surely space boots emblazoned with a Nike swoosh can't be far off, or images of happy astronauts swilling Budweiser beer through a straw or prominently reading The New York Times.

results.abstract: Russian astronaut hits golf ball off International Space Station in promotion for Element 21 Golf of Toronto (S)

headline.main: From Outer Space, a Cry of Fore!

results.snippet: In a promotion for a Canadian manufacturer of golf clubs, a Russian astronaut used a 6-iron to drive a one-tenth ounce golf ball off the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: It was a typical agenda for a spacewalk on Wednesday. Attach a space station antenna and install a proton detector to monitor solar eruptions. But first, some golf. In a promotion for a Canadian manufacturer of golf clubs, a Russian astronaut used a 6-iron to drive a 10-ounce golf ball off the International Space Station.

results.abstract: Nov 23 article about golf swing made by Russian astronaut outside space station misstated weight of ball; on earth it would have been one-tenth of ounce
results.snippet: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a golf swing made by a Russian astronaut outside the space station misstated the weight of the ball. On earth, it would have been one-tenth of an ounce, not 10 ounces.
results.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a golf swing made by a Russian astronaut outside the space station misstated the weight of the ball. On earth, it would have been one-tenth of an ounce, not 10 ounces.

results.abstract: Russian space agency is subsidizing its space program with promotion ventures and tourism; NASA refuses to pursue similar moneymaking ventures saying its job is space exploration and science, not advertising (M)

headline.main: Russia, Outer Space and the Profit Motive

results.snippet: The Russians take marketing to a whole new level  one 200 miles above the Earth.
results.lead_paragraph: With a foot jammed into a ladder to hold him steady, Russian astronaut Mikhail V. Tyurin sliced a lightweight golf ball into orbit last week with a one-handed swing during a space walk outside the International Space Station. The shot some 200 miles above the Earth was a promotion for a Canadian golf club manufacturer, which paid an undisclosed sum to the Federal Space Agency of the Russian Federation in the latest venture by the Russians to subsidize their space program.
